marc:datafield.marc:subfield: Henry Ellis (1757-1760) was governor of Georgia.
Documents signed by Ellis as governor of Georgia requesting tracts to be surveyed.

A receipt for rations for a small company of troops, 1786, and an affidavit of 1805 describing an encounter between Tories and Continental troops near James Butler's plantation in lower Georgia in 1780.
William R. Enecks was a cotton farmer and resident of Scriven County, Georgia.

Letters and papers of a Screven County, Ga., cotton farmer concerning the cotton and slave markets in Savannah; the wounding of his son in the battle of Atlanta; and contracts with freedmen for farming, 1865.
Thomas P. Elliott was a resident of Northhampton County, North Carolina.
Personal letters of Thomas P. Elliott, with descriptions of a train ride in 1834, a trip to the Middle West, and school life at Westtown School, near Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.
Letters expressing appreciation for having been invited to become honorary members of the Few Society of Emory College.
Henry Leavitt Ellsworth (1791-1858) was a businessman, agriculturalist, U.S. Commissioner of Patents, and a resident of Washington, D.C.
A true copy of the patent office record of a patent on cooking stoves.
Jeremiah B. Ellis was a resident of Fulton (Davie Co.), North Carolina.

Business papers of Ellis, of Fulton (Davie Co.), N.C., and other members of the Ellis family, including a ledger from a general store, 1852-1888, and a school records from Shady Grove, N.C., 1844, giving pupils, attendance, and some grades. Distilling from corn is also mentioned.
Ralph Waldo Emerson was a poet and writer, of Concord (Middlesex Co.), Mass.
Miscellaneous items including two original poems, "No fate save the victim's fault is low," 1877, and "To the Humble-bee."
Edwin Emery was a Union soldier, from Sanford (York Co.), Me.; and teacher, Southbridge and Whitinsville (Worcester Co.), Mass.

Letters of Emery written to his sister while he served in the Union army, describing camp life, the moral and religious attitudes of the soldiers, and the Battle of Spotsylvania Court House; and while employed as a teacher, discussing school curricula, discipline, and teaching methods.
Spotsylvania Court House, Battle of, Va., 1864.
Richard Elward was a printer, stationer, bookbinder, bookseller, postmaster, and a resident of Natchez (Nash County), Mississippi.

Daybook 1845-1847; subscription book, 1848-1852, from Elward's newspaper, the Mississippi Free Trader, including business letters and receipts concerning the newspaper and records relating to Elward's duties as postmaster of Natchez.

Collection comprises a letter Finley wrote to her mother, Ruth Finley. Topics included health matters, religious gatherings, spinning and weaving to make cloth, and visits to family members. A postscript was added to the letter, possibly by Ann's husband, that discussed the weather; pig slaughtering; planting crops of wheat, rye, and tobacco; and prices for pork, flour, and corn.
William H. Emory (1811-1887) was a graduate of the U.S. Military Academy; an officer in the U.S. Army; and a resident of Washington, D.C.
Correspondence, including a letter, 1851, from Charles C. Perry discussing a scientific project he was undertaking with J. L. R. Agassiz, Asa Gray, and Joseph LeConte.
John Willis Ellis was the governor of North Carolina (1859-1861), and a resident of Raleigh, North Carolina.

The collection includes a letter from Ellis, Governor of North Carolina, to John Letcher, Governor of Virginia, concerning a proposal to resurvey the Virginia-North Carolina border and a letter concerning a plan to divert all Southern trade to the port of Baltimore, Maryland.
Lemuel Ellis was a general merchant and justice of the peace, of Chatham County, N.C.

Letters and business papers containing correspondence with Ellis' brothers in Fayetteville, N.C., and Darlington, S.C., in the 1850s; ledgers of a general store, 1857-1863; court records, warrants, orders, and case accounts in the 1870s and 1880s.
Susan W. Empie was a resident of Richmond, Virginia.
Personal letters from Adam Empie to his daughter Susan regarding his travels.
Frederick David Ely (1838-1921) was a Congressman, and a resident of Boston, Massachusetts.
H. Ellis was a resident at Palmyra, Missouri.
Letter showing divided sentiment at the outbreak of the Civil War.
Thomas J. Elliott was a Confederate soldier from Chesterfield County, Va.
Family and Civil War letters from Thomas J. Elliott to his wife, giving brief accounts of the battles of Second Manassas (Bull Run), Drewry's Bluff, and Harper's Ferry, all in 1862.
John R. Ellis was a Welsh resident of Racine, Wisconsin, and an infantryman.

Collection includes one ALS dated 10 December 1862, from Ellis to "Ellen." Also included is a small unidentified diary in Welsh, with daily entries from 13 August 1862 to 12 March 1863. The diary is a detailed and colorful portrait of regimental life. The handwriting is the same for both the letter and the diary, and a type-written translation of the diary (included with the collection) notes that on 10 December 1862, the author "took several pictures. I sent one to Miss Ellen Pritchard." The above letter mentions an enclosed picture, although the photograph no longer accompanies the letter.
Unprocessed collection. Cataloged from accession record.
Letters written to Jose R. Emery by a female resident of Charleston, South Carolina describing the city while under siege during the Civil War.
